number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
r 8, 2016
												First Codemasters F1 game I've bought since 2013 having been disappointed by a glitchy throttle and force feedback (G27) and physics that weren't at all believable (I'm pretty sure with no TCs I should be able to wheel spin off the line...).Well, what a revelation 2016 has turned out to be! Rear tyres that want to light up, believable and predictable handling, stunning graphics and a game that truly captures the atmosphere of F1 (your team even deploys pit boards!). For me the handling is the star of the show. It may not be a full on sim like Assetto Corsa, but it rewards accurate driving whilst still being a little forgiving.The career mode is really nice, with programs to run in practice to hone your skills and the set up whilst earning development points. I can see myself putting in many hours to win the WDC with Manor!

content:
r 23, 2016
												The game seems a lot more polished than F1 2015 straight off the back. More graphics adjustments work really well with the PC, frames are more stable and a really nice level of customisation with things as little as camera angles and time of day editors. The new career mode is really nice - from playing F1 2010's career mode they've really improved on the great aspects they used before! The AI are still good, if a little too forgiving sometimes, as well as the contact model in most cases being spot on!

content:
er 23, 2016
												F1 99-02 was my favourite F1 game because it was the first one I got (and also for a long time), but now I truly consider F1 2016 my best F1 game.With the roots of the new engine monde behind F1 2015, Codemasters could have just re-implemented the career mode from F1 2014 and make it F1 2015 2. Instead they decided to overhaul the whole Career mode, add a new Time system to the weather system, give more depth with the character creation, improving some aspects of F1 2015...etcThe R&D system, which is the biggest change of the game, seems to be the one who anger a lot of the community, but it really rely on how you play : you don't have that much time and you want to quickly win ? Rush the R&D and make Haas Great Again. You have tons of time and you want to feel a more realistic competition ? Go slow on the R&D and beat the AI on tracks with skill.There are still some flows like the AI stacking themselves when some crash happened, or coming to pitstop for dry tyres just before the rain.But overall the game really made a huge step forward and gives a lot of hope from Codemasters, as lot of ideas in the game were given by players who answered a survey or by the forums (like the new Master Difficulty in one of the patches). Without comparing to others games of the series, I would rate it 8/10.

content:
r 1, 2016
												Overall a very good game. It does the F1 license proud. Graphically it is nice to look at. The game seems reasonably stable for me, with no crashes so far or fps spikes or any real concerns. The AI can be a little dopey but this F1 series has never been known for good AI. There is one but though...and it comes in the form of the blatent console porting. In this day and age it shouldnt be acceptable to not have the use of the mouse in menus. I am not interested in pressing the function keys to scroll around the various menus to set up cars etc. I expect to use the mouse. It is just laziness that companies still dont bother to implement mouse support simply because consoles dont generally use one. But that cant detract from the fact that this is a good game and worth getting, especially while its on sale.

content:
er 3, 2016
												This is an exceptional racing simulation game. It seems they fixed a lot of issues since the previous F1 2015, and for me F1 2016 has everything I could possibly want from an F1 racing simulator except one thing, TrackIR. However everything else is there, pit stops, tyre wear, excellent A.I. drivers, handling, controller support and vehicle customisation, dynamic weather, talking to the pit crew, etc.I have only raced the first weekend, I'm 8 hours into the game so far, and have 20 circuits to go, that's a lot of gameplay. The race is on to complete them before F1 2017 comes out. My only suggestion is to include TrackIR support, that would improve speeds and make this a 10/10, assuming the rest of the game is to the same quality - it deserves an awesome 9.5/10. Must buy.

Rush the R&D and make Haas Great Again. You have tons of time and you want to feel a more realistic competition ? Go slow on the R&D and beat the AI on tracks with skill.There are still some flows like the AI stacking themselves when some crash happened, or coming to pitstop for dry tyres just before the rain.But overall the game really made a huge step forward and gives a lot of hope from Codemasters, as lot of ideas in the game were given by players who answered a survey or by the forums (like the new Master Difficulty in one of the patches). Without comparing to others games of the series, I would rate it 8/10.

content:
ber 2, 2016
												An excellent addition to the F1 series by Codemasters. The last one I played was 2013, and having read the reviews for '14 & '15 I was glad to have missed them out. Short review: I would highly recommend this game to anyone who is a fan of racing sims in general, and obviously to those who like motorsports. This is the game we've all been waiting for.What immediately strikes you as you jump into Career Mode is the amazing feel of the cars and the sense of detail within the simulation. The set up of the car, in combination with the tyres, temperature, fuel weight and engine setting all play a significant factor on how the car performs. It can be a little daunting at first, but in practice there are three 'practice programs' that help you learn the tracks, and how to conserve your tyres, and what sort of times you'll need to achieve in qualifying. These programs continue to be of use even for those who master the car and track as they provide R&D points which can be used to upgrade the car as the season goes on. As such, as your season progresses, other teams may catch up with you, or you may leave them behind, and the likes of Mercedes are not guaranteed to dominate season after season.The races themselves are fantastic: the AI, whilst not perfect, provides an enjoyable, consistent challenge. It's certainly the most lifelike AI I've ever seen in a racing game. I've seen three cars attack corners at the same time, all exchanging positions, and I've been overtaken through late breaking etc. The AI can sometimes be a bit timid and give you too much space on lower difficulties - but once you start playing on expert, the AI really does provide an almost human like challenge. The biggest issue with the AI is that the jump up to the next difficulty can feel a little too much at times. This means that you might find yourself overachieving on one difficulty setting, but really struggling on the next difficulty up. The implementation of sliders would greatly help with this problem, but it is unlikely that we'll see such a system any time soon.By putting the damage setting to 'simulation' you'll witness fairly frequent (virtual) safety cars. In my last race in Canada there was two SCs following two crashes on T1 and T2 of the first lap, as well as for a mechanical failure late in the race. The SCs helped me conserve my tyres, so I was able to use a 1-stop strategy, which helped me finish in 3rd with a Renault, whilst my teammate got 5th. Other races haven't quite gone so well: at Monaco a rainy start called for intermediate tyres, but I was too quick to jump to slicks when the track dried and I lost quite a bit of time, finishing outside the points. Basically, anything can happen in a race: good fortune or bad luck, so you'll find yourself doing well some races but poorly in others - and the AI likewise struggles and benefits from certain conditions. This makes career mode far more enjoyable, since it's unpredictable and realistic, making the game very replayable.The graphics are very nice - not had any trouble with them following a couple of patches and updating drivers. This isn't an area of the game I'm usually too fussy about, but you can really see the effort Codemasters have made with the game, and it really does enhance the experience. I would say, however, that the sound of the game could do with some work. Bugs have made the sound a bit wonky at times, and the levels are not quite right, especially when passing other cars who are in the pits. Codemasters have already patched many bugs and addressed most issues, so I'm fairly confident that these issues will no longer be relevant in a few months time. In addition to career mode there is custom championships and time trial, although I haven't touch either game mode yet. There is obviously multiplayer - but I've never enjoyed racing games online, so again can't comment on that. To round this off I would say this is the best F1 game yet, it has fantastic replayability, graphics and gameplay. The simulation is the best it's ever been, and the practice programs are extremely useful tools for teaching people the tracks and how to drive quickly and smoothly. Whilst the difficulty settings could do with some tweaking and a few bugs in the sound department ironed out, this game is undoubtedly the new benchmark for the F1 series and is as good as a game we could have wished for.

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
ber 4, 2016
												F1 2016 is easily the best edition in the Codemasters F1 series that keeps pulling me back in to keep racing the way the previous titles couldn't. I mainly play sports career games, so a big welcome return in the player career mode where you can race as yourself amongst the field that was missing from 2015. The game allows you to somewhat design your own helmet, pick a number that isn't taken by the existing grid and a best-fit driver avatar before picking a team and getting the main game underway. It's obvious this is where Codemasters spent the time this year.Instead of breezing through practice, skipping straight to qualifying like days of old, you are now expected to earn research points via practice programmes that are spent to add updates to your car throughout the season. It is a requirement as the teams around you are continually developing their cars, so you need to too to keep pace. The programmes consist of tyre management, which provides you on tyre wear data for the race as well as research points, track aclimitisation and qualifying runs. They do a great job at making practice interesting and giving you tasks to do during practice helps with the immersiveness of the career.On a gameplay side, Codemasters have done a good job at portraying each car's strength, with the difference between say the Mercedes and Manor noticable, but not blindingly obvious. The handling of the cars feels good and overall the driving is solid. I found this not to be the case on a controller though, with the gamepad just not providing enough responsiveness to race quickly or competitively. It is good to see the safety car return too, this time fully controllable unlike previous versions as well as the new virtual safety car. Manual starts also make for good variation at the beginning of races and again just feels that bit more realistic waiting for the lights to go out.One area I am disappointed in is the difficulty options of the game. I find myself too quick for Expert difficulty but way too slow for Legend. It really feels like their should be a middle ground option between these two as I have seen many say the same.Presentation and graphics looks nice albeit the same as F1 2015. Bug fixes have been made since the game's release as well as improvements which suggests Codies are really listening to fans this year after taking their input in the game's design. Overall, F1 2016 is the best Formula 1 experience out there for me, and will keep you racing for a long time.8/10.

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
22, 2016
												Although the past couple of years left a bitter taste, I decided to take a leap of faith and get the F1 2016 game on pre-purchase offer and it was a good decisionI've only played 5 hours of the game and the impressions are so much better than 2014/2015 versions.Here are the things I most enjoyed during this short amount of time:The career mode is what makes it all fun, choose a low-end team and race your way to the top;Personalize your driver by choosing name, looks, nationality and obviously an Ayrton Senna like helmet;You can develop the car (R&D) along the practice seasons by completing some goals that will also help you to drive better;Control your entire career through your laptop;Beating your teammate is always rewarding;Get the best out of your car at the start of the race by feeding the throttle and releasing the clutch at the exact moment;Watch the pre-race and post-race actions.There are some downsides also:The AI keeps hammering your rear wing under braking, so annoying;There is still lots of wheel spin making it too arcade;After the rain, the track starts to dry slowly and naturally but then hits a turning point where it gets completely dry out of the blue and it is hard to define which strategy to follow.The FFB could be improved, the loose center is still there when using a G27 for example.Overall, it is a good game and in one weekend, I've already played it much more than the previous two versions.

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
18, 2016
												I'm pretty impressed with it. I generally prefer racing games that fall on the more realistic simulation side of things like Assetto Corsa and Project Cars. (More Assetto Corsa these days). I was a bit worried about how F1 2016 would feel/handle and FFB. I just spent about 40 laps at Melbourne in time trial mode getting a feel for things and once i got FFB and controls setup it feels quite good to me. I was afraid Assetto may have spoiled me with the SF15/F138 they recently released but i think the F1 cars in this game are very good and on par with the Assetto models. I only tried expert mode with all assists off and it seems quite "realistic" (Well as realistic as i'll ever know.. given i'll never touch one of these cars IRL)I had some intermittent issues with steering initially...1st: i had to turn my wheel all the way to get the car to turn at all.. the ratio seemed way off and too slow. found the steering saturation option and bumped it to 75 which seemed to fix that.2nd: occasionally i'd have an issue where i had zero FFB and the saturation setting above wasnt working.. It seemed to go away after crashing into something. (Using a Fanatec CSW V2) Time will tell if this persists.I'm not a huge F1 fan but watch with a passive interest. This is my first game from the official F1 series but overall i think this game is very solid. Looking forward to the career options. I dunno if you'd call it a sim or arcade or simcade, but at this point I think the physics are very good and will it will provide a lot of fun and replay-ability.Graphics look very good and i'm glad to have some unique tracks that i dont have access to from any other games like COTA and Singapore.

A.I., yep it's crap in lots of situations, but those that made me kill the f1 process and wait till A.I. Codenoobs update was - the flippin car won't move out of your way when you're in fast lap and they are not, it ruined so many perfect laps. Also in the race, if there is a crash in 99% of situations it will be you AND caused by A.I. crashing YOU, but nobody else. I'd still recommend it overall with a big BUT.This is the F1 game, the one we've been waiting for since Codemasters got the licence. It has a few quirks, but overall it's a massive improvement over previous games:- driving model, oh yes, steering wheel is finally the way to play this and it feels so natural compared to older games where you knew it's designed for controller and playing it with wheel just didn't feel fun, you'll get a proper feedback about what happens between the car and surface- active car development, player has complete control over what and how is developed- career - it's back, it's massive, it has tons of features and free practice is now the part where you WANT to spend a lot of time inBe aware of some minor bugs at the moment and A.I. weird moments, but still - much better than before. Nothing that can't be patched. It's new "Dirt Rally" in F1 world, you have my recommendation.I'll update the review as I progress.

content:
19, 2016
												Ok for starters I love racing games, but I don't know anything about F1 racing IRL.  I looked at the reviews on the previous games and didn't have high expectations for this game based on the older games.  I watched a few videos on youtube and thought that this game looked interesting and gave it a buy.  (I needed a new racing game for my Logitech G27 to be unpacked.)  I booted up the game and made sure my wheel was calibrated, jumped into a quick race... and was ♥♥♥♥♥♥ off that I couldn't move because the gas and brake were bound to the accelerator even after many times rebinding the keys.  Turns out I was not the game and instead a windows 10 issue that changed the Logitech launcher for the racing wheel.  I unistalled my laucher and downloaded a new one...http://support.logitech.com/en_us/product/g27-racing-wheel...And bam! Problem solved.  I am now racing.  The graphics are beautiful and the game runs oh so smooth!  I am writing this review after playing the game for 10 hours straight and loving every minute.  Had to take a break to eat and to avoid the pain from clicking through gears for so many hours straight.  The career mode had been super engrossing and I am finally getting somewhat better at the game and still trying to learn all the tire rules.This review is for all the people that want a good racing game, but may be turned off by some of the negative reviews from people that had problems with their racing wheels.  Oh BTW they already released a patch for the people out there that had some other wheels and some issues.  Great job with this game! It is a breath of fresh air for a developer to release a game that isn't broken for the first month after it launches.  Hopefully they will add some more customization content for the vehicles for free.  I would really like to see sponsor stickers, customizable paint schemes, ability to change helmets and get new helmets, and also to create your own racing team.  I would rate this game a 9.5/10 (Definetly worth a buy!)

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
20, 2016
												So far I've only done two 25% races at Australia. But so far things are looking good.I've been a little critical of Codies F1 games in the past. The reason for this is I'm a huge Geoff Crammond fan and always felt that Codemasters F1 games were a bit lacking compared to the Grand Prix series of games. Sure, they've always had better presentation than Crammond's Grand Prix series, but the driving just wasn't there. Sometimes it felt like the car wasn't even connected to the track. On top of this we had a very poor AI system.Starting with f1 2015 I felt that the handling model in Codies F1 games was starting to find it's sweet spot. It's not what I'd think of as "realistic" but it's got a nice balance. F1 2016 improves upon it. It's a much more pleasurable thing to drive now, and the car feels less like you're driving a bus. Couple this with an excellent career mode, better AI and new features like a slightly more advanced damage model and you have a very, very good F1 game.I liked it so much that I bought it on PC and PS4.

content:
22, 2016
												Although the past couple of years left a bitter taste, I decided to take a leap of faith and get the F1 2016 game on pre-purchase offer and it was a good decisionI've only played 5 hours of the game and the impressions are so much better than 2014/2015 versions.Here are the things I most enjoyed during this short amount of time:The career mode is what makes it all fun, choose a low-end team and race your way to the top;Personalize your driver by choosing name, looks, nationality and obviously an Ayrton Senna like helmet;You can develop the car (R&D) along the practice seasons by completing some goals that will also help you to drive better;Control your entire career through your laptop;Beating your teammate is always rewarding;Get the best out of your car at the start of the race by feeding the throttle and releasing the clutch at the exact moment;Watch the pre-race and post-race actions.There are some downsides also:The AI keeps hammering your rear wing under braking, so annoying;There is still lots of wheel spin making it too arcade;After the rain, the track starts to dry slowly and naturally but then hits a turning point where it gets completely dry out of the blue and it is hard to define which strategy to follow.The FFB could be improved, the loose center is still there when using a G27 for example.Overall, it is a good game and in one weekend, I've already played it much more than the previous two versions.

												Credit where credit is due - after several poor efforts from F1 2014 and 2015 and much criticsm, Codemasters have taken everything that was great about F1 2013, added significant polish and then provided a Career mode that at this early stage seems to be one that will keep me interested for many weeks and months to come.I have no doubt there are bugs and glitches to be found - although I have yet to find them - but I think Codemasters deserve huge praise for this effort. There are so mnay nice touches that add to the feeling that this is game that has been nurtured and enhanced for far longer than a year. It made me chuckle when I - driving as Lewis Hamilton - ran Nico off the road and Lewis had the audacity to give him an angry hand gesture. A little thing but in conjunction with all of the additions to this game it just reinforces the feeling that this is a quality product.It is still very early days so I'm sure there is a lot more for me to discover - good and bad - but so far my only issue is the force feedback on my Logitech Force GT. I daresay the various forums will find settings and solutions in the coming days but so far, all I can feel is an annoyingly harsh rattle as if I was hitting a speedbump at speed, periodically around the track. Other than that, my first experiences with this game have been delightfully, surprisingly positive.

content:
er 22, 2016
												F1 2016 is a great F1 game. Capitalising on the great handling + graphics combination produced the year prior, Codemasters spent the last year making improvements such as adding a thrilling and customisable career mode, improving online net code to a pleasant level, and perfecting what they had already done well. It's a game for all abilities, whether this is your first racer or you are a real life motorsport driver, you can blend the ai difficulties and assists to any level to utilise the generally realistic yet pick-up-and-playable handling model. It's not perfect as I'm almost making it out to be, but I'm really looking forward to the next release from a developer that's proved it knows what it's doing now.My personal experience has been slightly altered by having a graphics card driver problem in my first months of ownership which meant quick race was the only working mode, and also with suddenly receiving every Codemasters game I've been playing with them a lot recently too. I definitely should have more hours on this than I do!(Side note: I am able to run the game at 45-55 FPS on medium settings w/ an i7 and 750Ti so it isn't too hard to run either!)Pros:Realistic and rewarding handlingGreat, and quite easy to run, graphicsLow grip situations improved (grass on tyres, wet conditions, kerbs etc.)Intriguing career modeEasy to pick-up-and-play with assistsDecent/good online qualityBest AI yet (still room for improvement though!)Minimal glitchesVastly improved damage system w/ tethers and simulation settingsCons:Unrealistic/over-realistic in some situations (grass on tyres feels like being on a wet track on dry tyres, save me!)Pad steering is IMPOSSIBLE to be smooth (If Codies could bring back the slightest steering assist to all pad players to help situations where wheel is completely OP then that'd be appreciated)Not massively moddableOP tyre glitch (look up online if you don't understand what it is)A few other little things possiblyOverall, a big recommend, even if £40 is a bit steep it'll be about half that in the sales so do capitalise on it if you can!

content:
ber 30, 2016
												I've been playing F1 games and simulations all the way back to Grand Prix and Grand Prix 2. That being said I always look forward to a new game that tries to bring you that much more closer to the real life of a Formula 1 driver, and that much closer to realism. Every year since they got the rights I want to like Codemasters' effort into bringing me that experience and every year I get disappointed. It's not the game itself it's the 'effort'. Bugs, always. Lack of logic, always. They always seem to be their own worst enemy when developing these games. Don't LikeWet weather is better but still the game engine lacks the logic to know when it is wet and safe enough to run dry tires. If water is splashing up, it is NOT safe for dry slicks. My first wet race I was so excited then as the track (presumably) started to dry the AI switched to drys with mist still coming off my intermediates. WTF.The hospitality scenes. I get it, you want to make us feel like racing drivers but the whole cell phone, manager and engineer bit is just repetitive and annoying. Give me a first person view and be able to walk around the area, interact with people on my own for more immersion. Maybe I can call my manager and see if any teams are hiring (if i want to move). Maybe I can interact with the engineers to get more info from them on how to set up the car.No practice starts or focus on starts. Way too easy to get these cars off the line. There should be more focus on practicing your starts and if you don't get it right your car goes nowhere on the start.Pit stops need more interaction from the driver. Stopping long, short or leaving early/too late.I won't comment on my own experiences with my video card (can't overclock, crashes to desktop) because I think that is unfair given that is pretty much subjective.My likesDrivability is pretty 'arcade'. In my opinion Assetto Corsa or iRacing will get you to closer to the real feel of these cars sliding around BUT I like how forgiving they are even with TC off and using a gamepad. Progression is fun and doesn't make you feel like a losing battle as in previous years. In McLaren I am in the top 10 which by all means is not realistic but still it's your own adventure.Damage is much better and fun that it is easier to destroy your car because that's just how it really is.Ai is a lot more fun to race with.Even though I commented above about the weather dynamics and 'logic' around it,  it is much much more improved. The water drips off the mirrors and reacts so much nicer then anything else I've played.---I probably could talk so much more about this game. In the end if you love F1 then yeah I think it's ok. If you aren't, I still think this game will give you a good experience into the sport.

content:
29, 2016
												Introduction:If you are watching F1 grand prix including the practice sessions, and qualifying sessions and allways wanted to be in the shoes of some of the drivers from this year or in the future, this game will suit you. Carreer mode:F1 2016 includes all of the drivers and teams from 2016, and have a deep and engaging carreer mode lasting 10 years/sessions from 2016-2026 . In the carrer mode you can choose your tire strategy for each race and customize your cars in alot of ways to help you beat the opponents in the practice sessions and qualifying. Practice sessions:The practice sessions have alot of detail, including team-objectives where you learn how to save your tires and how to drive on the apex of the circuits. After you have completed the team-objectives you will earn funds, which you can use on various parts of the car f.ex. a better engine, more optimized fuel-systems , chasis-development etc.Race:After you have completed both the practice sessions and the qualification, you can choose to run a track parade, where you can increase the temperature of the tires.The AI cars race are very good, and have been improved from 2015, so f.ex. you will have less accidents with other AI-cars at the start of the race. There are 7 difficult levels you can choose from for the AI cars: "very easy" to "ultimate".Graphics: 95 /100The graphics of F1 2016 is improved from the earlier version and includes a full time-of-day, so you can f.ex. see the sun go down and lights turn on. The game includes dynamic weather effects, so you will have to change tires in mid-race if it's raining. The tracks have alot of detail and have more details than F1 2015.Sound: 85 / 100Sound is very nice with alot of details, like the sound of rain on the hood, the abillity to hear the other F1 cars engines both on track and in pit etc. The cars could have a better engine sound though.Performance: 95 / 100On my old Phenom 955 with 8gb of ram and a Nvidia GTX 960 I have around 39 fps with ultra settings and I haven't noticed any lag like there was in F1 2015.Overall: 92 /100The best Formula One game I have ever played!

number of helpful: 2 of 3 people (67%) found this review helpful
content:
24, 2016
												Video review is available here: 


YouTube™ Video:  

			Views: 0		



F1 2016 marks Codemasters' 8th iteration of the Formula 1 title, if you include F1 2009 which bizarrely only released on the Wii. After 8 iterations has Codemasters finally made the perfect Formula 1 game?This is so far the best Codemasters F1 game to date. I had a few issues with crash to desktop where the game would just close or minimise, but on the other hand I got several hours at a time without any such issues. I also had an issue with not being able to save my progress, or even start the game because it said C drive didn't have enough space (why this was an issue, I don't know, since the game is saved to a different drive with over half a terabyte of space) but after verifying the game files and rebooting my system (and uninstalling a few megabytes worth of programs), the game seems happy again (time will tell if the crash to desktop issue returns). Overall the game runs great at a considerably higher framerate than the previous titles pushing the 100s in places and otherwise sitting at 90 fps on high settings. I'm using a GTX 780 at 1080p and the game defaulted to high settings, and on max it should give a perfectly acceptable 60 fps, so if you have a 980 like the game recommends you should get an even better experience.Graphics are improved and the attention to the real sport is great. They've successfully 'game-ified' F1 and gotten across the more important technical parts of the sport. Codemasters has made changes to the Free Practice modes and have refined the free practice objectives. Each objective you meet gives you points to upgrade your car during the season and for me, this makes free practice worth doing again. For example, the tyre wear test teaches you how to go faster and preserve your tyres. You'll find yourself improving lap after lap and yet your tyre wear will get progressively better as your driving style becomes smoother. Track acclimatisation is something else they've put in. You get a series of gates to go through around the track and the faster and more accurately you pass through them the higher your score and the more development points you get. This not only teaches you to go fast, but also correct car positioning. Your personal tyre wear data can be used to create your pit strategy during the race which is great. Speaking of pit strategies, the game can now suggest new strategies on the fly depending on what's happening in the race so it's just like the real sport. On top of all that, if that wasn't enough, tiny differences like fuel load and tyre wear make a huge difference to the handling.Development points aren't just restricted to Free Practice. Development points are up for grabs all the way through a career mode weekend, be it for meeting a team objective, completing a certain number of laps in a session, beating your rival or taking home the big prize of a race win. Your performance not only nets you development points, but affects your standing within the team on the way to the coveted number one driver. The Development Points you earn act as an R&D currency, so the better you perform, the more points you have and the faster you  can get those sweet R&D upgrades. You get to choose to the development of your team in Career Mode and as your on track performance ties into so many different things, it's important to get out there and let your driving do the talking. With a 10 season career mode you can really stamp your authority within the team.Career mode boasts a leader board section which compares you against other players, based on the points you have earned so the competitive types should get their kick out of that.AI also suffer incidents, penalties and mechanical failures which should make the racing more interesting and unpredictable (having spent almost all my time online and only just starting career mode I can't say how much it affects races and can't comment too much on AI race craft). I'm just getting stuck into the career mode and so far, so good, everything you'd expect is present, including the Safety and Virtual Safety Car, which so far, are bug free. In races, blue flag AI works as it should, unlike some of the previous titles and I had little trouble getting past in the quick races I did. The safety car is here too along with formation laps and these are all bug free and working as intended so far. The only thing I would say is on the formation lap, the AI is too fast. They will go at racing speed off the line and will overtake you if you decide to slow down to do any tyre warming. I haven't seen them attempt to do any so far, but this will be different in career mode.The game also boasts support for custom drivers now, where you pick what you look like, your number, name, three letter abbreviation etc. and while this is a great addition, it would have been nice to see some more diversity in the faces (if you know what I'm saying). This feature could be further improved by letting the player choose an audio name. Other games from Codemasters allow it, so why not here? If this was allowed the commentators and pit crew could address you by name rather than 'a *car name here*'Online is fully featured, but unfortunately sees the return of hopper lobbies for sprint races. It would have been nice to have a session list like the custom races have as too often, I leave a lobby, search for a new one and get dropped back in the same lobby. Custom sessions have no such issue as the game provides a session browser so you can make informed decisions on which lobby to join. Players online are as you'd expect in any racing game and it's a shame nothing is being done (e.g. harsher penalties and safeguards such as ghosting blue flagged opponents) to kerb negative behaviour as it ruins what could be an amazing experience.Sound design is near perfect, with the engines sounding that little bit different to each other and the turbo whine (which some may find annoying) coming through on top. Coupled with a expanded pit radio voice commands, this is a very immersive title. The Xbox One controller is supported and the cars handle brilliantly on there, especially when you have a custom setup applied. The cars are tricky to handle and you can lose the back end incredibly easily if you're not careful. Setups see the addition of Steam Workshop support. You can browse the workshop at the start of a session or race and download a setup straight into your game for use there and then. This brilliant addition means, if you're like me, and don't want to spend a long time setting the car up, you can grab one from the workshop and be on your way.  So far, F1 2016 is a great game. I could go on as there's so much more to this game than you're willing to read. It takes the sport of Formula 1 and faithfully recreates and game-ifies it in what seems to be this series' Dirt Rally moment. It brings in features fans have been asking for, makes newcomers welcome with its video tutorials and refines old features with a level of polish we haven't seen from this series in a long time. Purists can argue that the lack of a Young Driver Test is a big negative, but honestly it's removing features like that which allow me to jump into a front running team in my first season. Provided you're not unlucky like I am when it comes to your games working properly, F1 2016 shouldn't disappoint.

As long as you approach it with that expectation I think most people will enjoy it immensely as I have!

content:
22, 2016
Product received for free
												The game features an enhanced career mode that takes place over ten seasons. Specific race goals are dependent on the strength of the team, and driver rivalries develop over time. A very neat feature is practice objectives: performing specific tests (like learning the track, conserving tires, or going on a qualifying run) will earn research points that can be spent on upgrading car parts. It is a welcome feature that gives a purpose to practice other than simply turning laps. In addition to the career mode, single seasons, quick races, time trials, and online multiplayer with full twenty-two car fields are available. A number of minor new features (the Azerbaijan street circuit, new Haas team, a formation lap, manual race starts, manual pitting, and the safety car) are also added for this year’s version. Racing physics are plausible, including tire wear, handling, and damage. Driving assists can be adjusted to support a wide range of player abilities, and flashbacks can be used to rewind time if needed. AI drivers are appropriately aggressive. F1 2016 is a slick, feature-complete simulation perfect for the racing aficionado.

content:
r 27, 2016
												7/10Even if you don't like open wheel racing, this is the best circuit racing game you can get on Steam.The things that are expected to be good, such as the racing physics, driver AI, and the overall simulation are all top notch. The racing itself may not be completely realistic, but this is a game, so compromises must be made to include things such as the Multi Function Display in order to remove frustration and improve enjoyment.While the game on the track might as well be perfection, the game outside of the racing could use a little work. Many cutscenes are locked at 30FPS, which can be jarring for users using a non standard refresh rate monitor. The Career mode's r&d programme allows you to develop your car at an unrealistically fast rate and car development is carried into the next season. Finally, I am disappointed in the lack of female driver avatars. Since there is no voice acting for the drivers, I don't see why there are no female avatars that would have made the game feel more inclusive.In general, the racing in this game is near perfect, but any other F1 fan can tell you there is more to Formula One and racing than what happens on the tarmac. I hope Codemasters can remove or ameloirate the faults in upcoming patches, which have already significantly improved the game.

content:
26, 2016
												Codemasters has been making F1 vidgames since 2009, now, in their 8th installation, I believe they've gotten a step closer to perfection. I have played every F1 game, but I only really liked 2013 (the V8s) and 2016. This game is rad -- the best one yet.  Category Rating (of 5) Reasoning   Graphics 4.5/5 Awesome variety of settings, didn't get perfect 5 because some textures are weak on the side of the track. The game is easy to optimize for a specific setup.   Sound 9/10 The car sounds are amazing and so faithful to the real thing. From the turbo whine and wheel spin to crashes, and rain starts, the sounds are AMAZING. Also, the various manufacturers' cars sound different from each other -- especially when braking (McLaren-Honda sounds way different from the Force India, for example -- S/O to  ♥♥♥♥♥ Tassles ).   Music 4/5 Idk, I turned it down, so should you. Engines are more important.   Cinematics 3.5/5 The intro stuff is amazing, but the career cut scenes, while beautiful in the background, leave something to be desired in the face department. For a racing game though? Top notch.   Story 5/5 A little spice and variety with contract changes, engineering stuff, and goals. Not obtrusive, but present and fun.   Content 5/5 Great variety for a racing game. Fun career, fast quick race mode, and simple multiplayer.   Gameplay/Controls 5/5 Simple, refined gameplay and controls. Great on controller, perfect on racing wheel. Easy to learn, difficult to master. They've added manual starts, formation laps, dynamic weather (get good at rain racing), and some other crud. The crashes are improved and more realistic. The AI is weak on the bottom 3 settings, casual on the middle one, and a good challenge on the final 3 -- you'll adapt. The upgrade system is way cool and encourages thoughtful and engaging play through the entire F1 weekend.

content:
ber 13, 2016
												This is a light hearted review, nothing to be taken to seriously but before I get into that, I would fully suggest buying this game if you're a F1 fan, I've spent 8 hours in total in the game and I've only just completed the first GP, FP1 and the rest actually mean something now and the AI are somewhat competent enough to respond to your moves. Now for the things that amused me.Seriously now though, within the first 4 laps of race day Lewis pinched me off track to overtake resulting in a nasty 720 spin and a puncture, didn't even get a penalty! (Realism, eh!? ;) )"Shut up Jeff!" totally works too, never had more fun asking for more updates and then telling him to shut up half a lap later, made the straights a little bit more entertaining when I wasn't close enough to creep up the inside of the car ahead. Lewis didn't get 1st place on the podium yet still jumped around and celebrated, that's certainly a minus in the realism points... (Lewis gets some flak in this review, before you jump at me though I'm not an out and out hater of Lewis) Oh and yeah, Max double blocked me...Either codies have been hard at work or just coincidence but I had to laugh. Great game, very much an improvement over all the others.

												I have owned all the F1 games from codemasters since 2012, and after the big disappointment last year with F1 2015 this years F1 2016 is actually the best one i have played so far. Running smooth on my 970 GTX in 1920x1200 with ultra details.Buy it!

content:
ber 4, 2016
												I haven't bought an F1 game since F1 2012. I felt that they generally started to follow a formula (lolpun) and got into somewhat of a rut.I'm happy to say that this one completely smashes it out of the park. Absolutely everywhere where F1 has stumbled in the past has finally been addressed. For instance, the feeling that you were never really driving other cars during qualifying, and that it was all faked to give the illusion of a close session. All that is gone. You can now watch your AI competitors via their onboard cameras whilst parked in the pitlane.The AI feels consistent through each round of the calendar too. In previous years I would find that I would struggle to qualify in Australia, but be pole position in Bahrain. Now it feels that over the year they stay competitive. From what I am hearing too, the AI seems to pose quite a challenge. I'm only playing on Hard AI difficulty right now, but I feel like I might be able to put it up a notch soon.I think my new favourite feature for this particular outing of this franchise though, is the practice sessions. They finally feel worth doing. The track acclimatization and tyre wear tests make practice feel meaningful.I recommend anyone who has already bought the game to put the damage up from "Full" to "Simulation", (it makes no sense to me that there is a setting above full but whatever). Simulation tends to lead to more AI faults and crashes leading to two safety cars so far, one real and one virtual, but they all add to the excitement of each race. This makes the damage particuarly unforgiving however, leading to more than a few tyres hanging on by their tethers, (which looks awesome by the way).All in all, this is their best yet, and I really think this is up there with the great Geoff Crammond Grand Prix 4. I really recommend you give it a go.

												1st of all The game was extremly well optimised here (PRECISE HERE), i have a solid 60FPS with everything between HIGH/ULTRA (x16MSAA), 1080pRIG:i5-4570 @ 3.20GHz8GB of RAMGTX 1060 (8GB)Game install on HDDAbout the game, I expected nothing from so I am pleasantly surprised to see the quality of F1 2016.Driving is pleasant, easy but tricky once some aids disabled :) The career mode was pretty great tbh, i enjoy it so well ! 												So, i've been away from PC driving sims for some time.  Largely because i got rid of my wheel, and also because every sim I've tried in recent history has had inferior driving 'feel' to the gran turismo series on the playstation when played with a controller.F1 2016 feels 'right' to drive.  I'm using a 360 controller and feel that i can do with the car what i want, and handling feels like it should, given that i have never driven F1 before, the physics seem feasible.The AI is particularly good, and a vast improvement on anything i've played before.  Out brake a rival into a corner for example, and they will give room and try to cut back, rather than just plow into you or back way off like in other games.  There's actually some semblance of intelligence there, rather than just sitting on line.Recommended.

												I am just starting out on it. I have had bad experiences with F1 2014/15. The return of the Career mode was vital. It saves this game and makes it very much playable. A bit more english humour and a more intelligent race engeneer and this would be perfect for me.Thank you to codemaster for finally listening to the fans. More reality, more fun, more story line...and here we are, raised from the dead! Thank you!

number of helpful: 0 of 1 people (0%) found this review helpful
content:
19, 2016
												TL;DR It's very good. For sure Codemasters best F1 game to date. But has notably problems like fairly passive ai. It's also buggy and Codemasters tend to spend little time fixing bugs. Could be truly great if they put effort into improving it.Having done my first two career races I can happily say it's good. Not perfect, not by a long shot. I'd stop short of the glowing review above, but it's good.Notable down sides, bugs, there's quite a few, including a hilarious one where I'd got distracted by real life so had to restart my first race (I hate restarting). Apparently when I restarted, Haryanto was going through a foam sign at the time, so when we restarted I noticed that the game had decided to remember that. His car had foam constantly bouncing out the back of it. It was amusing if not somewhat distracting.My biggest criticism however is the AI doesn't seem as punchy as it was last year (one of last years highlights). They have gone back to the, oh, I'm on the outside, I will back off now mentality. Also, and this annoys me, they refuse to cut across if another car is on the outside around a corner. So in Bahrain where I had a ridiculously good position on the grid compared to Australia, (either luck, learning how to drive or a balance issue) I saw Hamilton and Rosberg spend about 6-8 corners side by side..... That, kinda, wouldn't happen. So it seems the ai isn't aggressive enough. I haven't seen any ai tangle with each other yet.Also, another thing, the ai is weird on the first lap, they all bunch into a close nit line. Now, I don't know if they use different ai on the first lap, or, there's a weird catch up thing going on, (god I hope not), but it feels very weird. They all seem to go the same speed (or close too) After the first lap it's fine though. Once you hit the first round of pit stops there's cars doing all sorts of things, which makes it feel really alive, if not slightly hard to follow.The strategy, both race and long term development is fantastically done. There tyres really feel like a choice. The pit crews often (too often), gives you alternative strategies to switch to during the race. I say too often, because as I was desperately trying to cling to 11th with 2 laps to go in Bahrain (it didn't work, I feel to 14th), it was just, really distracting. No, I don't want to pit with 2 laps to go. Stop asking. Also, stop telling me you'll let me know if there's a storm front on it's way. In Britain, sure, but I'm racing in Bahrain. It just sounds silly. So, the radio is still a bit annoying, even if it is much better. (The options you have to interact and the information you can get are much better).Obviously the game is build to be used with (if you like) voice commands for the pit wall, however I haven't seen any way to actually make it respond to my headset. It would be disappointing if it wasn't in built in this years version, (last years required an external program).Oh, another thing and this really ♥♥♥♥♥ me, I use a G27. If I hit a button on the keyboard, the little tooltips for what each button does relates to the keyboard, it'll tell me F5 swaps pages in the set up screen or something. But if I hit a button on my wheel, all the tool tips turn to Xbox controls. What button on my wheel is X, I ask you. Unless the game is being played with a controller, it should never come up. Why can't the tool tips just reflect what's in the settings menu? Why not let the player customize the out of race bindings as well?Oh, another thing, the VSC is awesome, but, it needs to show your delta in the middle of the screen and have it larger. (I'm sure mods will make this happen). Because the pint sized text box on the right is damn hard to see when you're trying to keep to is through a series of corners as well as trying not to run into anything or miss a braking point. Also, entering the pits, you have to manually slow the car. I like that. But, it's damn hard to make sure you're going 56 and not 61. (Melbourne was not a good race for me).I really like this years game so far. But good god, a lot isn't bugs. It's just, obvious stuff they they either haven't got around to or are oblivious too. It's painfully obvious that it's a port.Worth noting, it runs very well and it's looks good as you would expect. The sound is good, but the volume of the competitors is too high, so you think there's a car coming up behind you and he's actually five or ten seconds behind. There seems little difference in sound between a car on your gearbox and two corners back.So, that's my thoughts so far. Defiantly their best game. Far from perfect. Driving as K-Mag's team mate in the Renault. 0 points for the team so far. Solid start I think. But I am beating K-Mag.A quick few things that are great, the rivalry system is just, amazing. The race starts are fantastic the physics are really a highlight I think. Sound is solid, the career mode is back and is well done. Although, really it should be standard fair. The last bad thing I'll say is this, unlike most games I buy, I have little hope that Codemaster's will significantly address issues with the game (apart from game breaking bugs). The tight schedule means they don't spend any time really improving the game post release. I hope that mods can fix some issues, but from last year they basically killed off the modding scene as they made it impossible to mod most things.

number of helpful: 0 of 1 people (0%) found this review helpful
content:
19, 2016
												TL;DR It's very good. For sure Codemasters best F1 game to date. But has notably problems like fairly passive ai. It's also buggy and Codemasters tend to spend little time fixing bugs. Could be truly great if they put effort into improving it.Having done my first two career races I can happily say it's good. Not perfect, not by a long shot. I'd stop short of the glowing review above, but it's good.Notable down sides, bugs, there's quite a few, including a hilarious one where I'd got distracted by real life so had to restart my first race (I hate restarting). Apparently when I restarted, Haryanto was going through a foam sign at the time, so when we restarted I noticed that the game had decided to remember that. His car had foam constantly bouncing out the back of it. It was amusing if not somewhat distracting.My biggest criticism however is the AI doesn't seem as punchy as it was last year (one of last years highlights). They have gone back to the, oh, I'm on the outside, I will back off now mentality. Also, and this annoys me, they refuse to cut across if another car is on the outside around a corner. So in Bahrain where I had a ridiculously good position on the grid compared to Australia, (either luck, learning how to drive or a balance issue) I saw Hamilton and Rosberg spend about 6-8 corners side by side..... That, kinda, wouldn't happen. So it seems the ai isn't aggressive enough. I haven't seen any ai tangle with each other yet.Also, another thing, the ai is weird on the first lap, they all bunch into a close nit line. Now, I don't know if they use different ai on the first lap, or, there's a weird catch up thing going on, (god I hope not), but it feels very weird. They all seem to go the same speed (or close too) After the first lap it's fine though. Once you hit the first round of pit stops there's cars doing all sorts of things, which makes it feel really alive, if not slightly hard to follow.The strategy, both race and long term development is fantastically done. There tyres really feel like a choice. The pit crews often (too often), gives you alternative strategies to switch to during the race. I say too often, because as I was desperately trying to cling to 11th with 2 laps to go in Bahrain (it didn't work, I feel to 14th), it was just, really distracting. No, I don't want to pit with 2 laps to go. Stop asking. Also, stop telling me you'll let me know if there's a storm front on it's way. In Britain, sure, but I'm racing in Bahrain. It just sounds silly. So, the radio is still a bit annoying, even if it is much better. (The options you have to interact and the information you can get are much better).Obviously the game is build to be used with (if you like) voice commands for the pit wall, however I haven't seen any way to actually make it respond to my headset. It would be disappointing if it wasn't in built in this years version, (last years required an external program).Oh, another thing and this really ♥♥♥♥♥ me, I use a G27. If I hit a button on the keyboard, the little tooltips for what each button does relates to the keyboard, it'll tell me F5 swaps pages in the set up screen or something. But if I hit a button on my wheel, all the tool tips turn to Xbox controls. What button on my wheel is X, I ask you. Unless the game is being played with a controller, it should never come up. Why can't the tool tips just reflect what's in the settings menu? Why not let the player customize the out of race bindings as well?Oh, another thing, the VSC is awesome, but, it needs to show your delta in the middle of the screen and have it larger. (I'm sure mods will make this happen). Because the pint sized text box on the right is damn hard to see when you're trying to keep to is through a series of corners as well as trying not to run into anything or miss a braking point. Also, entering the pits, you have to manually slow the car. I like that. But, it's damn hard to make sure you're going 56 and not 61. (Melbourne was not a good race for me).I really like this years game so far. But good god, a lot isn't bugs. It's just, obvious stuff they they either haven't got around to or are oblivious too. It's painfully obvious that it's a port.Worth noting, it runs very well and it's looks good as you would expect. The sound is good, but the volume of the competitors is too high, so you think there's a car coming up behind you and he's actually five or ten seconds behind. There seems little difference in sound between a car on your gearbox and two corners back.So, that's my thoughts so far. Defiantly their best game. Far from perfect. Driving as K-Mag's team mate in the Renault. 0 points for the team so far. Solid start I think. But I am beating K-Mag.A quick few things that are great, the rivalry system is just, amazing. The race starts are fantastic the physics are really a highlight I think. Sound is solid, the career mode is back and is well done. Although, really it should be standard fair. The last bad thing I'll say is this, unlike most games I buy, I have little hope that Codemaster's will significantly address issues with the game (apart from game breaking bugs). The tight schedule means they don't spend any time really improving the game post release. I hope that mods can fix some issues, but from last year they basically killed off the modding scene as they made it impossible to mod most things.

ber 25, 2016
												After 23 hrs playing updatedLets start withCons-I use a wheel, haven't tried the keyboard, but the controller is twitchy. If you find it that way, there is a fix for it, you need to edit action_map_preset_win file, xi_preset1 or preset2 steer left & right deadzone 0.0, I also set saturation to 0.0, try out what works for you. I also add 5 to steering linearity-AI bumps into you too much, hopefully patch will fix it. I drive in a straight line, without trying to block AI & they still run into the back of my car.That's about it for the consPros-AI is challenging on MEDIUM+-Graphics are pretty good-Feels amazing with a wheel (without any adjustments), I usually drop down the force feedback since i find it annoying at 100%-Career mode is pretty amazing-Great physics & cars feel smooth-Love the new engineer updates!-Codemaster keeps putting out patches!-Steam workshop makes it easier to pick Car SetupsKeep up the good work Codey, best racing game I have ever played, hands down!

content:
ber 7, 2016
												As much as I'd like to give this game a positive review, there's a couple things that make parts of this game unplayable. Now I've been looking forward for the "upgrade to f1 2015", or you know, a complete version of that game. And this game does do that. By implimenting the career mode (and all of its nice little quirks), the game has some definition other than just time trial and quick race. The offline AI are alright, they let you attack pretty easily as to avoid a collision, but actually defend a little bit. My main problem with the game is the online AI. You might think this is one problem who cares, but to me it's extremely prevelent considering I like to play with my mate, but the online AI have something to say about that... We are playing on legend so if it isn't hard enough to keep up and overtake, the AI will literally break poorly (either into you or early in front of you), and completely ignore your existance if you're not the host. Even if you are th host, it's not as good as single player AI, which once again, are just OK.In closing, this is a great single player racing simulator if you like Formula One, but the online is shotty at best at the moment, and Codemasters are literally on vacation 10 months out of the year, so I won't be expecting much of a patch for these AI anytime soon.

number of helpful: 2 of 6 people (33%) found this review helpful1 person found this review funny
content:
er 16, 2016
												Overpowered Split stream from the built in AI system carries over to online multi-player making online racing a slipstream fest. Games physics model leave contacts made during close racing and battles pron to accidents,  resulting consequences   are lost/damage front wing or spin. The net-code is better but still needs work as cars will lag and cost you time or damage. The top 10 runners during qualifying gets a tyre wear glitch where they have significantly more tyre wear than the rest of the grid on harder compounds. F1 2016 Will need more fixing and patches as The safety car is back but does not function properly making league races long and boring with no forceful strategy calls. The VSC is also bad, you can accelerate during the VSC period right before green flags gaining an advantage over your rivals. The only thing positive that could be said about F1 2016 is that the handling model is better than F1 2015. 6/10 for me as the game is full of graphical bugs for PC users making driving at times un-raceable as the screen freezes and stutters through out a race. It's sad COdemasters can get a budget build a game on it, make a profit on a release then just leave the current game in it's state. 7 patches does not fix a game which in my opinion was not ready for release.

												Garbage AI doesn't have any player awareness, will drive you off the road, sandwich you in turn 1 or rear end you in the braking zone. Have restarted Melbourne Career race a dozen or so times because the AI kept crashing me in the wall whilst not having made it to the first ♥♥♥♥ing pitstop...Safety car is crap aswell, has no ♥♥♥♥ing logic to it. It's also rather rubbish to spend 2 seasons getting a Manor to the front and then deciding, well, on to the next. There's no sense of investment if you can just hop over to the next for a rinse and repeat since well, it doesn't feel like you've build up your car to the max whilst outperforming the other teams....Driving is good enough for 2016ish but the AI, Safety Car and R&D are just lacking, especially the bloody ♥♥♥♥ing AI that can't do anything but put you in the goddam wall.

												If you are an F1 fan, a driving sim junkie or even a casual racer this maybe worth checking out. The driving mechanics work well and feel responsive. The driving assists and difficulty are fully customizble, so you can set the game up in a way that suits you. An interesting career mode where you get to earn points to reseach car upgrades, there are customizable car setups, practice programes and 21 circuits amongst other things. There is a lot to like here. F1 2016 is a great racing game in all aspects.On top of that the game runs very well, and Ive not come across any bugs or crashes in my time with the game. Highly recommended. This is more fun than I thought it would be. Worth checking out! Codemaster have done a great job with this.The only caution is if you dislike racing around the same ciruit 50+ times, becasue you will be doing that in the full weekend modes. This game require soem patience. It is F1 after all. Also it didnt detect my MS wheel, even though it works in other games and is detected in windows 10. content:
er 13, 2016
												What looks like being the best F1 game so far is spoilt by the fact that it is not playable on a fairly high spec PC that runs other Steam games without any problems whatsoever.  Merely completing a quick 5 lap race at Austria makes the game crash to a blank screen resulting in the need to hard reboot my PC.  I can repeat this consistently.  Despite contacting Codemasters directly and being advised to start the game in safe mode and verify the integrity of the game cache, making sure all drivers are up-to-date, this game will not run properly.  What a huge disappointment.  I'd been looking forward to the release of F1 2016 for months.  How could Codemasters have got this so wrong?  It doesn't fill me with confidence about any future titles.  As a software test analyst by profession, it's clear that this game has not been tested properly before release and are relying on gamers who buy the game to identify the issues but don't even bother to fix the issues that are raised.  The issue I'm having seems to be common among other gamers too!  Poor!!  I'd like my money back please!!

												I  have the impression to be a beta-tester with a SLI configuration with 2xGTX970 and W7 Pro 64 bit and triple screen at 5880x1080.Changes on 24 August created some modification to the settings. In addition to the previous very annoying and continuous noise buzz that has not been fixed, I have to check and try several settings to finally found the one that remove some blickering and some sort of darker halo two meters in front of the car.I had to put almost everything maxed out in terms of settings for that (except the two "off" recommended by Nvidia for 3D settings: for "particles" and “?). Therefore my fps is averaging 30-36 (without 3D surround of course).I have to say that I consider this game unfinished and therefore I stop to be a beta tester and I return to F1 2012 with the wonderful mods created by the community (realism patch, HD texture for the circuits and the cars etc.) where I can enjoy better quality racing from my cockpit and fps around 100.I will come back and maybe modify my rating when a solid patch settles these issues. In addition the absence of support for TrackIr5 and the engine noise that I hate do not contribute to my desire to come back before these points are fixed (for engine noise: a mod from the community).

content:
r 30, 2016
												After all the hype, more stuff to play with, the interaction of engineers and your agent, i went ahead and purchased the game, I have been a F1 fan since the 70's and never miss a race, so i donned my gloves and helmet and started to play.Well, talk about shampoo rinse and repeat, i didnt have it on the hardest level as i really dont want to throw my controller at my rather large monitor, but to say i was bored to tears by Monaco was an understatement.I won all but 1 race, even stopped upgrading so they opersition can catch me, but then i fell into a deep sleep at the wheel and never played again.The game to me seems very so so, good GFX and music/sounds, but, its the pratice sessions and qually that bore me, after time when you done that your left with the race, many times i just quit because i just couldnt face the race after all that "junk" to qually and get points in practice to earn better parts.So all in all, i just found it very repetitive, you know what the engineers going to say, you know what your agents going to say and you know you will end up winning.For me, its just another boring F1 game that still falls short of what it really should be, although they did try hard to get it right, there is some sweet spots but for £40 it was a waste of cash, my opinion you may like it as many do, but its a matter of rinse and repeat, a lot!

content:
21, 2016
												I have three reasons why I would recommend not buying F1 2016.. yet?1) This should obviously be driven with wheels and pedals, and Codemasters haven't made that a comfortable experince. There are huge deadzones on both the brake pedal and the throttle pedal. It's especially bad on the throttle. I've simraced for about 8 years and I've never experienced such massive deadzones. There's an aproximately 30% deadzone on the buttom of the brake, and a 25% deadzone on the buttom AND top of the throttle. I have no issues in any other of the racing games/sims that I usually play. This should be easy for Codemasters to fix but it's appalling that such core settings aren't made properly from the start.2) The shiftlights cannot be moved. The last F1 game I bought and played was 2011. It really borthered me that the shiftlight indicators couldn't be moved. I suspect the reason for that is that they need to port their games to consoles, but that's speculation. I wasn't really surprised to see they're still immovable, it is Codemasters afterall.3) The sound is absolutely messed up. Even using the "full soundscale" setting, sound is messed up in a couple of ways. The most obvious is that the other cars are waayyy too loud. Way louder than your own car. Also, there seems to be too few sound channels to handle all the noises when you're running in a large pack of cars, makes the car sound like robots beint brutally mistreated instead of expensive racecars.The game has a lot of potential. I hope codemasters patch the game. The physics are decent, the grapics and framerates are good. I'll change my review once I find the game in an acceptable state.

number of helpful: 4 of 18 people (22%) found this review helpful
content:
24, 2016
												QUICK UPDATE: I'll re-write my review later tonight but I felt it was necessary to say that the replay issues has been patched yesterday. I've been playing the game quite a while now after being able to fix the controller near-decently so I'll re-write it later.First of all, if you have a Steam Controller and plan to play the game with the gyro wheel: DO NOT BUY THIS GAME. It doesn't work.Now, I've read reviews of people saying this was not only the best F1 game ever, but the best RACING game of all times. Are you all high?? I'll make a simple list of game-breaking bugs that are in the game right now.- If you have any controller or wheel other than those officially supported, they won't work.- Even if you have a wheel or a controller listed as compatible, like my Steam Controller or a G27, they still might not work properly.- The Steam Controller comes as supported, they even made a very complicated default config with gyro steering controls... TOO BAD IT DOESN'T WORK IN THE ACTUAL GAME! The game considers the Steam Controller as an X360 gamepad so it applies all the dampening and limitations of a thumbstick to your motion steering wheel, making it IMPOSSIBLE to play. If you want to turn, it will go straight. If you want to go straight, it will turn. You wanna go right? he'll go left instead! Garbage. Absolute garbage.- The AI. Don't get me started. You're driving on your line, on a straight, you're not moving around... BOOM. the AI car behind you decided to go full nuts on your backtrain and crashes you out of the game. They don't even try to overtake you on the free side... I've had a car on the Spa straight after the Eau Rouge that tried to overtake me ON THE GRASS. and then crashed on me!- Performance is terrible. I have an R9380 that can run Doom at ultra at 100 fps and I have to run this game at ULTRALOW (!!) and I can't still do more than 50 fps. Then you go into the flashback/replay, and it drops to 1,5fps, you wait 15 seconds, the replay finally shows up but it runs at 9-10 fps.it's a pity. knowing Codemasters they will now release a couple of patches, two months between each patch because console-patching costs money, and then they will go silent for a couple of months until they will announce their new super hyped F1 2017. this game could have been really good. I believed in that. I believed we could finally have the F1 game we've been promised since 2012. But no, another broken game, promised patches that will bring out more bugs and then Codies will go like "next year it will be better!"if they don't fix this there will be no next year for me. I've already skipped buying the 2014 and the 2015, this one looked promising but I'm out of here seriously if they leave this game like this.

content:
22, 2016
												I thank you for releasing a new F1 game. It's probably the best since 2013. Congratulations. However, the team that develops F1 could have done a much better job if they corporated with the DR team, and also had took a look at other racing games. It's not easy to be the racing company for years, but Codemasters has to acknowledge they are surpassed by other companies now. The list: - No pit-limiter button- No ingame or outgame eyefinity adjustement (Assetto Corsa ingame or Dirt Rally outgame)- No softlock - No wheel rotation or wheel ratio adjustment (270 - 420)-  No option to disable wheel and arms.  (Can be modded. Racedepartement)-  FFB is dead on straights, etc. (No minimum FFB force, etc) - No advanced FFB settings.- Eyefinity is streched. - Bugs here and there. - No trackir/opentrack support. - No camera-adjustment by buttons. -  See-through mirrors. - Can't allow or disallow racingline and other assists in multiplayer racesettings. - Not able to disable  or skip the cutscenes. - If you have more than one device it will keep asking to insert buttons for the other devices- Can't adjust subtitle-frontsize- AI is awful. Always following the ideal line, rubberbanding, braking too much when SC is out, etc- Crashes are hilarious- No marshalls cleaning debris when someone crashed. - Can cut every corner you don't want to cut in real life. - Flashback is a must when blue flag is out or AI overtakes on long straights. They will crash you. - Debris laying on the ground. - No trackrubbering in this game. - and moreI thank you for reading and I wish the F1 team a bright future. Ivy

content:
ber 8, 2016
												They are getting better with this version for sure. I like a lot about it but find that it fails to deliver the smoothness I look for in the graphics, particularly with the anti aliasing effects making everything look a bit jagged in the distance, and for me personally, this is a deal breaker and find that sims such as iRacing have much better AA effects in place. Graphics are not everything of course, and I find the graphics in F1 very decent, although found no way to improve the AA to a satisfactory level even on ultra settings. I wanted to love this game though as they nailed it with all official teams and tracks, which is very cool. No on else out there has the lisence to F1 but codemasters. The career mode seams to be very indepth and well made as well as unique, although the character animations are very cartoon like which puts a damper on giving the game a simulation feel, but the wide array of options settings for the cars and view and such are nice and give a simulation depth. The force feedback seems much better than past versions as do the physics, so well done there.Better AA and better frame rate optimization may have kept this game in my library rather than ending up as a refund. SO close, yet so far away. If the lack of smooth edges in the distance and overall doesn't bother you, or if your system does a better job than mine smoothing them out somehow, this may be right up your alley if you're really into F1. But for me, close but no cigar quite yet.Perhaps next season they'll perfect it and I'll be back with a stellar review...until then....For an in depth unbiased review from inside sim racing, check out my link in the comments section below.For those of you more interested in fanboy comments or perspective written while intoxicated on sublime ganga smoke... check out Tzukasa's replies below.

												HUGE ASTERISK NEXT TO MY NO VOTEThe game in terms of content and mechanics MORE than makes up for the previous 3 installments.The issue I have with this game is the controls. I'm not entirely sure if its me or if the game is glitched, but I've been experiencing numerous instances where controller inputs (be it a G27 or Xbone controller) either hang, are slow to respond, or don't respond at all. This is game breaking as it makes it impossible to mantain smooth inputs and lines while racing around.I feel that, despite the nice amount of content within the game, it was rushed and gameplay bugs were overlooked. A little bit more in terms of developement time would've been nice I think.

												Started the game for a quick race at Silverstone. Got as far as the first corner before it locked up. Ctrl-Alt-del kill process and it wont restart. Reboot PC will start. 2nd corner locks up .... etc. My PC exceeds the recommeended specs. As a big F1 game fan very disappointed.
